5.56.text:
So in Silicon Valley there's the fail fast
fail forward the fetishizing of failure and

13.31.text:
I think it's extremely misleading and misinterpreted
and misapplied in many cases.

18.94.text:
So whether you ask say Peter Thiel who views
failure as always being a tragedy, there is

24.12.text:
no exception, it is not some aesthetic imperative
or learning imperative necessarily.

30.76.text:
Or you talk to say Mark Andreessen, for instance,
who I interviewed for the Tim Ferriss Show

35.52.text:
but also for Tools of Titans and he says,
when I was getting started, I'm paraphrasing

39.79.text:
here but when I was getting started we didn't
have a fancy word for it we just called it

44.22.text: We didn't call it a pivot.

45.39.text:
I think that it would be better to say iterate
fast and iterate forward.

53.14.text:
So there's no problem with getting say feedback
on a minimally viable product or an earlier

59.47.text:
So Reid Hoffman, another person I've interviewed,
founder/cofounder of LinkedIn and the Oracle

67.27.text:
of Silicon Valley as he's referred it to even
by a lot of the elite investors, for instance,

72.72.text:
in Silicon Valley, believes that you should
effectively if you're not embarrassed by the

77.19.text:
first version of your product that you ship
you're too late.

80.50.text:
And it's true I think in software development
and different types of user interfaces and

87.34.text:
so on, but it's not always true for say a
book or other types of creative endeavors.

93.13.text:
So it's a case of being very specific in what
you mean by failure and also making sure that

101.27.text:
what you/re transplanting from one area to
another, if you are doing that, actually applies

106.71.text: in your industry, in your trade, in your craft.

109.86.text:
But I certainly feel like doing your homework,
coming out and maybe the Silicon Valley ethos

120.19.text:
should start looking to the military more
to say I think it's David Hackworth, I think

125.91.text:
I'm getting that right, who said if you find
yourself in a fair fight you didn't prepare

130.11.text: properly or something along those lines.

133.12.text:
I mean it is entirely plausible and possible
to come out and just smash your competition

138.68.text: from second one of round one.

141.15.text:
And I think even if you do end up failing
and then correcting course that's a good aspiration

146.33.text:
to have, not to come out really shoddy and
handicapped from the get go expecting to pivot

153.78.text:
Then if you look at my portfolio, for instance,
I have about 70 companies I've invested in,

158.62.text: I was a pre-seed advisor to Uber.

162.59.text: And Uber's business model hasn't really changed.

164.62.text: It's been the same for a very long time.

166.51.text:
If you look at Derek Sivers the founder of
CD Baby, he came up with the business model

170.79.text:
in about five minutes of going to a used record
store and asking them how they did it.

174.84.text:
And it remained the same effectively for ten
years, 15 years until he sold it for whatever

181.95.text:
So you don't have to fail, it's not a prerequisite
for having a successful company or a successful

187.43.text: life, you just have to learn.

188.96.text:
So I think learning and iterating are two
words that are going to be more valuable than

193.39.text:
failure, but when failure does slap you in
the face, when fortune serves you up a title

197.39.text:
wave of some type or quicksand, being able
to adapt to that and not emotionally overreact

202.89.text:
I think is certainly important, but you shouldn't
striving for failure.

207.89.text:
If you look across all of the icons, titans,
world class performers that I've interviewed

213.45.text:
in the say wealthy section, if we're dividing
them into healthy, wealthy and wise, when

219.01.text:
you look at the business side of things one
of the most common patterns that you spot

228.35.text:
And the power of the absurd question is really
something that I've paid a lot of attention

233.15.text: to in the last few years.

235.05.text:
Whether that's say Peter Thiel, so serial
billionaire, certainly an incredible entrepreneur

239.68.text:
but also an incredible investor, good at betting
on presidents it turns out as well.

246.06.text:
And he would ask questions such as why can't
you accomplish your ten-year plan in the next

254.57.text:
And if you talk to say Peter Diamandis, Chairman
of the XPRIZE, he might ask the founders of

261.12.text:
companies he's looking at as potential investments,
if you had to 10 X the economics of your startup

267.18.text:
in the next fill in the period of time, six
months, three months, how would you do it?

273.00.text:
And if they say it can't be done, that's not
something we can do, it's impossible, his

277.11.text: response is I don't accept that answer.

281.84.text:
Those types of questions, I think whether
it's 10 X thinking, 100 X, however you frame

287.36.text: that, it could also be a constraint.

290.43.text:
For instance, if you had to accomplish all
of your work or grow your company two X while

296.72.text:
working two hours a week, if you had a gun
against your head how would you attempt to

301.67.text:
These type of absurd questions don't allow
you to use your default frameworks for solutions.

309.76.text:
They don't allow you to use your base of current
assumptions to come up with answers.

314.18.text: It forces you to think laterally.

315.57.text:
It forces you to break some of the boundaries
on the sphere of comfort that you've created

323.20.text:
And that is what makes them I think in a way
so powerful.

326.13.text:
And these are not questions, by the way, I
think are valuable if you ponder them for

331.78.text:
ten seconds and go hum, yeah maybe I would
do this and then move on with your day.

336.56.text:
I think that journaling as an adjunct to asking
these questions is very, very important.

342.07.text:
So I will sit down very often in the morning,
one of my rituals also borrowed from a lot

346.77.text:
of these people is morning journaling of some
type.

348.83.text:
And I tend to use either morning pages five
minute journal or just a separate type of

353.73.text:
freehand sort of goal dissection and this
would be a case where I would ask one of those

358.58.text:
questions and I would write freehand for say
three pages, three to five pages and drink

364.18.text: some tea as I'm doing it.

365.66.text:
And that is when you will not only come up
with interesting ideas, and they might be

370.36.text:
90 percent garbage, but if you have ten percent
that lead you in an interesting direction

375.73.text:
that could completely revolutionize your business
or your life if you take that seed and do

382.38.text:
And that's been the case for me for a very
long time.

385.34.text:
I actually created a list at one point after
observing this pattern among these people

389.39.text:
I was interviewing and I just made a list
of what are the most absurd things I could

393.10.text: do right now related to my life and business?

396.19.text: And I created this long list.

398.88.text: And some of them were terrible.

400.02.text:
I mean literally I was at a conference I was
bored and that's why I was doing this and

403.75.text:
some of them were very specific business related,
one of them was cut off my own feet.

411.81.text: You can't see but they're intact.

413.71.text:
And at the same time though one of them was
take a complete break from the startup investing,

418.30.text:
so retire from startup investing because that
had become a source of stress due to the inbound,

426.87.text:
And that was a real game changer for me taking
my indefinite startup vacation about two years

432.60.text:
ago, which has led to incredible growth in
other areas including in my own businesses.

438.60.text: So there you have it the power of absurd questions.
